It's really not a great movie or anything that special, but I saw it when it was in theaters and it's special to me, probably because it's one of the few comedies to deal with gamer culture. It's not like it handles the material terribly well, or with any depth, but it's nice to see the subject in general. Honestly I wish Hollywood would make a few more comedies about the lives of gamers and those who work in the industry. Another thing to note is it captures a certain golden time for gamers: The PS2/Xbox/Gamecube era where the future looked insanely bright and we were just drowning in good games from all angles. It's a fun time to revisit and this movie reminds me of it in so many ways. For the nostalgia trip alone I have to give it five stars.

While having discussions about modern comedies, and thinking about which films will stand the test of time, the film, Grandma's Boy is always brought up, and I could never understand why. I saw this film when it first came out and was less than impressed, still I'm constantly hearing about the film and decided to give it a second chance, to see if I was missing something. What I always admired about this film, was that Adam Sandler finally gave his underlings the chance to shine. With experience comes knowledge, and the possibility of being more than just one liners in the middle of one of his films, that was the hope anyway. The story follows an adult game tester named Alex (Allen Covert), who is forced to move in with his Grandmother and become part of her Golden Girls lifestyle. Along with her and her roommates, there are several funny moments, but nothing to write home about. The rest of this film just isn't that funny! Most films about losers, connect to the audience and make you pull for them in the end, but when it comes to Alex, I just really didn't care all that much. In typical Sandler form, there is a girl and some weird conspiracy involved, but the whole thing wasn't even good enough for the man who starred in Jack & Jill, so to call it one of the funniest movies of all time, it isn't even close. It's evident to see what the writers were going for, but the fact of the matter is, that the characters just aren't that interesting, and the film isn't raunchy or slap-stick enough to be anything more than a passing memory.

"Grandma's Boy" is all about Alex, a 35-year-old video game tester who finds himself needing a temporary place to stay when he is suddenly evicted due to a problem with his roommate and overdue rent. Alex tries to stay with friends, but this doesn't work out, and he soon finds himself moving in with his doting grandmother and her two friends, highly medicated Bea and bitter, promiscuous Grace. Balancing the world of his co-workers/friends (mostly twenty-something stoner gamers) and the much tamer, though just as strange world of his grandmother and her roommates is difficult for Alex at first, but he eventually finds they are able to mesh rather well. A little too well sometimes. Things aren't all wine and roses though, as one excluded co-worker with a massive ego and bizarre behavior has his sights set on the same upper-level beauty as Alex.

From the folks at Happy Madison (full of those Happy Madison familiar faces), the 2006 comedy "Grandma's Boy" is a hilarious (if constantly crude) comedy from start to finish. Yes, there is a lot of stoner humor in this film, but you don't have to be a stoner to enjoy it. At its heart is a story about a guy a lot of gen-Xers and post-gens can relate to quite well, just trying to find his place in a much more complicated world than ever before without settling for less than what he's passionate about. It's partly a romance, like most good movies, but for the most part, it's all about laughs and telling a great story that actually feels quite original in its simplicity. A lot of it just feels like you're hanging out with friends and having a great time! The cast is superb, with Happy Madison regular Allen Covert taking the lead for a change, supported by the outrageously funny Nick Swardson and Peter Dante, and even Jonah Hill in one of his first movie roles. Linda Cardellini is the girl of Alex's dreams, Samantha, brought in to make sure the newest video game is finished on time, and she is a perfect fit. And Doris Roberts stars as Grandma Lilly, who is the perfect loving grandma. Her two friends are played by Shirley Knight and Shirley Jones, and yes, Shirley Jones is a freak in this. Watching her get nasty these days is like watching Carrie Fisher in "Fanboys". You wonder, would you still make out with her? I mean, if I think about Shirley in "Oklahoma" hard enough, I just might. Man, she was an angel in that movie. Anywho, she's no angel here, but she is incredibly funny! Bottom line, "Grandma's Boy" is perfect if you're looking for a relaxing comedy to just laugh out loud at, and this movie has everything. Even a monkey! The way it's been heralded as a fantastic "stoner flick" is kind of underestimating it, in my opinion. I'd just say it's a fantastic comedy for gen-X and younger (adults only, of course), sort of like a Kevin Smith comedy, like "Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back", but more Happy Madison-ish, if that makes sense. Oh, and did I forget to mention Joel Moore as the villainous weirdo, J.P.? That guy is a riot in this flick! Do yourself a favor and check this underrated (now a cult favorite) film out! It really annoys me how some real gems like this one and "Hot Rod" go unnoticed in theaters and not quite as funny flicks like "Superbad" and "The Hangover" get so much praise. Though, I have to admit, I think Grandma's Boy and Hot Rod got a lot less promotion, as I recall. I always thought it went direct to video.

The DVD for "Grandma's Boy" is widescreen with the option of an unrated version, and it's well stocked with bonus features too! You get a director commentary AND a three-actor commentary (always enjoy group actor commentaries!), plus lots of deleted and alternate stuff, a music video, behind the scenes material (even on the music video), and, of course, the film's trailer. It really is a fantastic buy that I highly recommend!

Boy stars Allen Covert in the title role. You may recognize him from Adam Sandler's films, like The Wedding Singer, where he plays Sammy, the friend who wears the Michael Jackson-esque outfits and drives a limousine, or 50 First Dates, where he plays "Ten Second Tom," the dude who gives a whole new meaning to the term "short-term memory," to name a couple.

Anyway, Boy is the story of man-child Alex, a 35 year-old man who holds a career as a video game tester. Hijinks ensue when Alex is forced to move in with his loving grandmother, Lilly, (Doris Roberts - Everybody Loves Raymond), and her two roommates. "Silver Fox" Grace (Shirley Jones) has the libido of a 20 year-old, while Bea (Shirley Knight) is over-medicated to the point of Terret's Syndrome.

Alex, of course, does not want to admit that he lives with his grandmother, so he tells all of his friends and co-workers, including sexy new boss, Samantha (Linda Cardellini), that "three hot babes" live with him. The real fun begins when it is revealed just who these "three hot babes" truly are.

Even a stoner flick has to have conflict if it hopes to mimic some semblance of plot, and that's where rival co-worker J.P. (Joel Moore) comes in.  J.P. has some some serious identity issues (read as: he thinks he's a robot), and he is always working against Alex to try and present that next new idea before Alex, or anyone else, can.  But now Alex has a plan up his sleeve to expose J.P. as the psycho he truly is (not that he needs much help in that department).

If you like stoner humor that consists of, among other things, karate-chopping chimps, men who talk like robots, pop culture references, drunken karaoke, unfortunate incidents with Lara Croft dolls, and sexual innuendo galore, then you too could be Grandma's Boy - well, depending on how liberal your grandma is, of course.

I wasn't sure what to think when I rented this initially. Sandler's sidekicks have been funny, but never had to carry a movie. The movie is not deep or thought provoking, but the tons of one-liners and ridiculous antics of Dante will keep you laughing all night long.

At 35 years old, Alex (Allen Covert) tests video games for Brainasium, the company behind the wildly popular game "Eternal Death Slayer". When he discovers his roommate Josh (Jonathan Loughran) hasn't paid the rent for the last six months because he used the money on Filipino hookers, he finds himself going from place to place to find his ideal crashing ground. But the last place he'd wind up staying would be with his Grandma Lily (Doris Roberts), the only one who gives him a place to stay in exchange for doing chores around the house. Lily shares her home with two friends, Bea (Shirley Knight) and Grace (Shirley Jones), who keep Alex busy nearly every night. As soon as Alex's co-workers find out, they don't know the real story. Meanwhile, Alex is trying to charm Brainasium's beautiful new executive Samantha (Linda Cardellini) while dealing with the firm's space-case CEO Cheezle (Kevil Nealon) and J.P. (Joel David Moore), a teenage game designer who dresses up like Neo from "The Matrix" and speaks often with a robot tone.

If there's one thing I learned from Adam Sandler, it's that the movies he produces and doesn't star in don't turn out to be as good as HIS movies. Stinkers like "Joe Dirt" and the last "Deuce Bigalow" (look for a reference in this movie) come to mind. As far as I'm concerned, his latest effort from the Happy Madison camp, "Grandma's Boy," has a few redeeming parts. But with a better director (Frank Coraci or Peter Segal), this could've been a laugh-a-minute rival to last summer's gross-out comedies.

But inside all this craziness, there's some good things to lampoon. One of them is the video game industry, where many of the guys play video games like "Dance Dance Revolution" (watch this movie for the scene alone) or whatever. However, director Nicholaus Goossen (Allen Covert's assistant on "Eight Crazy Nights") sadly shifts the action away to some unfunny points, like Alex pleasuring himself to a Lara Croft doll or anytime Joel David Moore is on screen (the robot voice isn't really that clever to begin with). And Adam Sandler should know better, after producing good movies like the most recent remake of "The Longest Yard."

There are some good actors in this movie who are game. Shifted into focus for the first time, Covert somehow seems bored out of his mind when delivering several of his lines and, as I said before, Moore is a one-note joke. But Sandler finds his niche with his other co-stars, such as Nick Swardson (a stand-up comic from Comedy Central) as Alex's often buddy. And Linda Cardellini scores when she drunkenly performs Salt-N-Pepa's "Push It" - she's easily above this juvenile material, along with senior actresses Doris Roberts (still funny even after "Everybody Loves Raymond"), and Shirleys Knight and Jones. Sadly, cameos from David Spade (as a fruity waiter) and Rob Schneider (as Alex's tenant) are wasted.

But there are hosts of other good performances. Loughran could've used more screen time, as with what he's got to work with, he could've easily taken this show to new heights. And leave it to Peter Dante to chew up the scenery whenever he mentions about different types of weed. If only Peter Segal directed this movie, the jokes could've taken off, because Goossen doesn't have the imagination and handling of comic timing for this to happen.

But, regardless, this still is a funny movie.

It's rare that I give a comedy five stars, but "Grandma's Boy" is perfect.  Comedic timing, a brief romantic angle, wonderfully silly acting and a fun plot make this one of the most perfect comedies I've ever seen. Allen Covert plays Alex, a recently homeless video game tester who's just looking for a break.  He visits his local weed dealer, played tightly by Peter Dante, to see if he can stay at his house for awhile.  Alex has second thoughts about staying there when he finds out that Dante's African tribesman buddy, Dr. Shokalu, has acquired an actual lion to protect the stash.  His next attempt at bedding down is with his game-testing buddy, played with stereotypical geek charm by Nick Swardson.  His sleepover experience at Swardson's home reveals that Swardson still lives with his parents, has a lot of toys, and a really cool car bed.  It also leads up to the first really funny (and really wrong) confrontation involving Covert and one of Swardson's family members.  From there, Covert ends up staying with his grandma, Doris Roberts, who is basically playing a role similar to that of hers in "Everybody Loves Raymond," but with a whole lot more edge.  She and her two roommates, Shirley Knight and Shirley Jones (Partridge Family), welcome Covert into their home with open arms.  The result is an all out pot party, geriatric sex, geeks fulfilling their wildest dreams, a kung-fu chimp, dance dance revolution challenges, vegetarian humor, a game programming scandal and a ton of other things that just don't belong together but somehow work here.

There is also a romantic angle to the story involving the cute Linda Cardellini (Freaks and Geeks, the Scooby movies).  "Grandma's Boy" takes care to not drag the comedy down with the love story as I've seen in countless other comedies these days.  Cardellini plays Covert's new supervisor, and they become close friends as the story rolls along.  Even she manages to become part of the lunacy when she takes the boys out one evening.

A number of SNL alumni are in this flick.  Rob Schneider makes a brief appearance as Covert's landlord.  Kevin Nealon plays the holistic owner of the game company Covert works for.  The scene stealer, however, is David Spade as Shiloh, a sexually-questionable waiter at a vegetarian restuarant who takes on Covert and his buddies while they're celebrating the completion of game-testing.  The only SNL omission is Adam Sandler, who's Happy Madison company produced this flick.  However, it's obvious that he put his stamp on this movie.  It features the same stable of actors that are featured in almost every other Sandler flick out there.

This movie is wrong in so many ways, but that's what makes it fun.  The really amazing thing is that all of it is pulled off with little or no actual offense to those who are made fun of, and that's an amazing feat these days.  If you love dirty comedies like "The 40 year-old Virgin," "There's Something About Mary," and "Wedding Crashers," you're sure to love this flick.

I'm usually leary of anything bearing Adam Sandler's Happy Madison production label, but much to my surprise, Grandma's Boy is a blast.  Allen Covert (who also co-wrote and produced) stars as a 35 year old video game tester working on a hit new game, and in his spare time he is secretly designing his own game while smoking a lot of marijuana.  When he gets kicked out of his house, he ends up living with his grandmother (Doris Roberts) and her two room mates (Shirley Knight and Shirley Jones) while dealing with his best friend (Nick Swardson), his ultra tan dealer (Peter Dante), his super hot new boss (the ultra hot Linda Cardellini), and some other weirdos as well.  Despite it's predictable plot and gags, Grandma's Boy works mainly because of it's stars and the blast they're having filming it.  Covert, Swardson, and Dante (all of which had a hand in either writing or producing the film) are quite funny in their roles, with Swardson stealing the show as a granny loving master of Dance Dance Revolution that still lives with his parents and sleeps in a race car bed.  Frequently funny and enjoyable throughout, Grandma's Boy is a surprising stoner comedy that is better than one might think, and it's certainly better than anything that Adam Sandler himself has headlined in the past few years.  Frequent Sandler cohorts and SNL alumni Kevin Nealon, David Spade, and Rob Schneider all have brief turns in the film as well.

Allen Covert, who we all know from his character parts in numerous Adam Sandler movies, stars in this film. The movie definitely has a familiar Sandler-type feeling to it, but I thought it worked well with the given cast.

It all starts out with a hilarious scene where Alex (Covert) is being evicted from his place while playing video games. It turns out his roommate has acquired a penchant for Filipino hookers and he's spent all the rent money on his addiction. It sounds pretty weak, but it's a great scene and it's really well done.

A good number of actors make guest appearances. Rob Schneider is the Middle-Eastern landlord, David Spade is a feminine waiter at a health food restaurant, Kevin Nealon is an overly spiritual boss, the kid from Dodgeball (Joel Moore) plays a video game designing genius who has a robot as part of his dual personality, the mother from Everybody Loves Raymond plays Alex's grandmother... Nick Swardson (who is a professional stand-up comic) is hilarious in his role as Alex's best friend at work. He really adds to the movie with his personality and one-liner delivery.

There are some really good lines in this movie, as well as some strikingly funny scenes. I found myself laughing out loud more than a few times. If you liked early Sandler movies, you will definitely appreciate this kind of humor. The Unrated version is raunchy and even better than I was expecting it to be. There is also a good deal of bonus material, including some featurettes and deleted scenes.

Kevin Nealon does a small role similar to his zen golfer in Happy Gilmore, David Spade cameos as a gay waiter in a vegan restaurant and Rob Schneider has a scene as the landlord who throws the main character out.  You'll recognize plenty of other Happy Madison alum through out.

In the extras, brief vignettes about the "bathroom scene" and the monkey are funny and appropriately short.  I also watched the deleted scenes, which had a few laughs. I didn't check out any other extras, but enjoyed those.

I won't buy this movie, but I will definitely watch it if it's on HBO, and I'll recommend it to my friends who aren't easily offended.

Grandma's Boy is stoner humor of the best kind.  And knowing that's what it is, you can have a great time if you go into it with that level of expectation.  This is an Adam Sandler production and it shows in the sophomoric, body and stoner-based humor that pervades this film from start to finish.  But it IS funny, again, if you are a fan of this type of humor.  If you like movies like Old School, Anchorman, Up in Smoke, or Half Baked you'll like Grandma's Boy too.

The special features are, unfortunately, not all that special.  The deleted/unused scenes get parceled out over several different headings and even get repeated from one to the other.  There's a montage of all the pot-smoking that goes on in the movie as well as a music video and an accompanying making of featurette.  There's a casting call show that is interesting, but too short to really be informative beyond how excited they were to get Doris Roberts to play the titular Grandma.  Finally there are two different commentary tracks, one with the director and the other with several of the actors.

I would easily recommend this film to fans of the genre, and at the current price it's a bargain.
